title: [RE-INTRO] August "groovylord" Browning, Champion Design/R&D
body:
Hi friends, I'm August.
[I did an intro post a couple months ago ](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/developer-corner/GMbEvaqv-intro-august-gypsylord-browning-champion-designer) and I figured now would be a great time for another as I'm about to both change my screen name AND change teams.

WHO AM I?
I'm a megagamer who loves thinking about how to design resonant characters.  I grew up in Alaska, majored in economics at Dartmouth, and then started at riot immediately after graduation. This month marks my 4 year anniversary with the company and I've loved every day of it!  I used to be an almost-pro TF2 Scout/Medic(logged like 1400 hours into that game) before switching to League around the Malzahar patch. Am currently a D2 support main.

On the subject of the name change.  I've used the name "gypsylord" for the past 12 years.  It was a homage to my first doggo, Gypsy.  Growing up in the US (and Alaska especially), I never realized how racially charged the term "gypsy" is in parts of Europe.  I've gained a more global perspective over the years and so I'm making the personal decision to move on from my old handle and start with something new.

WHAT DO I DO AT RIOT?
For the last 4 years I've been a champion designer.  I designed the mechanics for Vi, Jinx, Ekko, and Jhin.  Also worked on Gnar w/Meddler  I spent the first 4 months of this year working on what was to be my final champ, but ended up handing him off to Jimmy "BeatPunchBeef" Steorts in May.  He's still a long ways off, but you guys are gonna love him for sure. Super exciting character, can't wait to see where Jimmy takes the concept.  

As of about a month ago, I've moved off of champion and onto a team in our R & D department.  Sadly, I can't say much about what I'm going to be doing asides from we're still trying to get that "S" into Riot GameS and I'll be continuing to leverage my strengths at designing characters.  Hoping to learn a lot and eventually deliver some awesome experiences to all of you in the far future.

Asides from direct mechanics design I have done other things!

 - Was heavily involved in early concept ideation for many of the champs developed in 2014 and 2015. 
 - Headed up the keystone mastery project with Stashu and Squad5 and convinced them to add a 3-hit passive to every champion in the game.  Thunderlord's wooooooo.
 - Worked with our skins team on gameplay clarity (if there were any unclear skins released over the last year you can blame me D:)
 - Moonlighted as a live designer for a month and half where I proceeded to bop Kindred (hopefully for the last time) and attempted to Unbench the Kench.

WHAT DO I WANT TO TALK ABOUT?

This will be similar to my last thread.  Feel free to ask me about any of my past champs or projects.  I'm their #1 fan and know A LOT about them, be it theme, lore, or mechanics.  Also , if you want to know anything about growing as a designer (or just as an employee at a company) I can speak to some of that.  I started out here as a baby, and had the immense privilege of being able to learn from a lot of talented people older and more experienced than myself. Perhaps I can pass some of those learnings on to you!

And of course, if you have anything you want to talk about outside of those topics feel free to bring it up.  This can be an AMA of sorts. Can't guarantee I can respond to everything, but I'll try when it falls within my sphere of knowledge.  I'm on a recruiting trip in Boston at the moment so I'll be hopping in and out to respond to things over the next week.
___________________________________________________
**UPDATE --- WILL BE HOPPING IN ON AND OFF THROUGHOUT THE DAY FOR THE NEXT WEEK. Will answer as much as I can.

Do you see Ekko as a tank bruiser top laner or as an assassin, I wanna buy ekko and main him, but I'm not sure what's the best thing for him, also did you have passion for champions design before you started with Riot, or Riot games was the reason u loved champions design job

Similarly I see Jhin as a burst mage (ala Xerath or Veigar) that FEELS like an ADC.

And then Vi is a punch girl (ala Vi and Vi) that FEELS like a punch girl.
No offense, but I've sort of felt that Vi could've/should've been more like Riven, but with punching. How did she end up with her current playstyle?

Which is exactly what comes to mind if you think about some Punk Gal with huge hextech fists

On a champion design perspective what are your thoughts on Mordekaiser.
He may be my main (with over 640k mastery points) but I've been really enjoying Vi and wanted to know what her designer might think about a champion design as ancient as Morde^^

I think his passive has some pretty extreme game health problems that we've never really been able to resolve.

I just feel like scaling a melee character's defense with their ability to maintain damage up time is a formula for disaster.  You get this binary experience where if he can hit you he'll keep hitting you and never die and if he can't hit you he's squishy as hell and dies in the blink of an eye.  Original Skarner had similar problems when his shield refreshed from basic attacking.

Overall Morde's kit is too binary as a whole, he needs more variant actions that result in differing levels of success, right now it feels like he just statchecks you. (similar to old AP sion)

PS, he is ult is mega awesome though.  Enslaving the enemy ADC and Dragon is great thematically and strategically.  The base kit is what needs work.

Also feel like the real thing we need for Morde is a VGU on the scale of Poppy and Sion.  This guy could be our METAL AS HELL DEATHKNIGHT.  I think there's sooooo much potential in that thematic space.  He could be so cool!

Defense scaling on offense is a really weird thing in general as there are way too many variables in that equation.
Enemy MR, your own damage output, etc.
Though you gotta agree that it's very Juggernauty in a sense that he gets tankier the more people he faces head on, could be made a ton more healthy though by changing it to a fixed amount like Darius and Illaoi(Do you even spell it like that??).

I strongly agree on the binary part though. Morde's entire success relies on getting items and just trying to flatten you, there's no middle ground. He gets in range and he'll win, he gets kited and there's nothing he can do.
Kinda comes with his entire kit being 100% damage with...more damage.

His conquest over enemy souls is certainly one of the high points of his kit and makes him very unique (though new yorick does tap a bit into the spoooooky ghost unit aspect) and it would be a shame if it would not be preserved in his future VGU.

On the topic of his passive though, which I only now realize is kinda similar to VI's blast shield in a sense, do you feel a damage oriented melee bruiser would potentially work with a shield that has a very high up time (current Morde having shield 100% of the time) or do you feel it creates this unsatisfying experience of never being able to truly chip away at his health?
Strong shielding certainly is Morde's second most defining aspect but it just feels... Unfair? I guess due to how little downtime it has.

More intuitive shielding would certainly be something that would be less painful to balance, huh?

Also sorry if I just go on and on about Morde, I kinda enjoy talking about him with Rioters^^

You enjoy talking about Morde??!?!!?  Never would have guessed ;)

I think IDEALLY, better patterns are stuff like Yasuo and Vi shield or Darius and illaoi Q's. More gated moments of large healing/shields instead of repeated moments of small shieling.

That doesn't mean that repeated shielding can't be solved.  I think a version of this that worked really well was old Vlad's drain tanking (once we got his laning under control). Old Vlad was a squishy dude that relied on large amounts of healing and spell vamp to keep himself alive during fights.  What made it work on him I think is that he never really got that tanky, so even if his health bar was constantly moving up and down, bursting him with Veigar was still always an option.

It's really about, when this character is going off what can opponent do (that isn't a stat check) to still have a chance vs. them.  If we can make a repeated shielding pattern where there's still options for the opponent (that don't leave the player feeling like trash) then I think it'll work.

I feel what kinda contributes to Morde's shield becoming like this huge grey wall the opponent can't seem to crack is how negligible his health cost seem to be.

Which brings me to the topic of resources.
You've designed champions who use mana to resourceless ones like Gnar (well, technically he works on a certain rage-bar for other abilities)

Recent champion releases have been either mana users or just resourceless but there wasn't a single recent champion who uses health as a resource.
Is there a particular gameplay element to HP users that made them trick to balance or was it just a thematic reason?

Brings me just back to Morde (funny how it always gets back to this, huh?) who has been a terror back when 13hp pot and a rejuvenating bead start used to be a thing, even worse when a revolver was his first buy.
A shield whose efficiency relies just on SPAMMING with no real decision making (was kinda amended with his new E) and that costs only a little bit of health for such a big reward just seems to be unintuitive by design.

Wouldn't some kind of proper resource management be what would differentiate the smart from the dumb usage of a shield?

Also, it really shows how out of date Mordekaiser is with all the new champion design philosophies and I'm honestly amazed how he managed to remain like this for a very long time. Might be due to him being Shelved like some other champions whose kits aren't really in line with League's current design.

I've seen you comment on FroMA being somewhat of an icky thing regarding Gnar using it so efficiently and just had to think about Morde's own unhealthy relationship with Rylais.
So, on a design standpoint should there be an item that provides CC for champions to make up for some of their shortcomings or does it just create abuse cases of those building it who wouldn't need it in the first place
Gnar himself having a ton of mobility, CC in his kit but still end up getting the item.

Is there a place for these items and can they be part of certain champions core build without just becoming really huge gameplay problems if champions just end up overly reliant on them?

Sorry to keep the Morde train rolling (not sorry), but do you think Morde is a good candidate for either a full or partial revert on his updated kit. The reason I ask is that his new kit seems to have all the same problems that Kogs update did.

1. He is very, very feast or famine.

2. If he reaches you, you are dead and you can't kill him. If he doesn't reach you he does nothing. And in effect he mostly becomes a stat+proximity check (or a tonberry -> Chef's knife, stabby, stabby).

3. While there are other offenders, Morde feels like the biggest offender by far with Rylai's. While most others are strong or annoying with it, his power is almost entirely tied to its slow.

A revert wouldn't exactly put him a good spot like Kog since he was never exactly in a good spot to begin with, but old Morde seems healthier (more counterplay, less stat-checky), more dynamic, less game warping (especially around rylais), and has a better fallback pattern in pushing/waveclearing.

It's this pretty much.  While new Morde isn't ideal, I'm not sure old Morde is all that much better, so I'm not sure how much a revert would actually get us

What about Sona?

Her old kit was changed for very specific reasons, according to claims made at the time not due to the kit being healthy, and these goals were both not met and in some cases made worse. Sona's kit right now is just unbalanceable due to the method of applying and scaling effects.

I'll be the first person to say the old Sona kit would be on the weak side thrown right into the current times, but it would be a much better start point for further improvement.

Old Sona's kit had a problem.  The auras made her incredibly hard to balance because their power to satisfaction ratio was way off. Basically, she FELT way weaker than she actually was.  This was a character who typically sat at one of the higher winrates in the game.  Whenever we nerfed her we'd get waves of negative sentiment about how we were making her unplayable (even though she'd remain at a high winrate).

This is what ambient stat auras tend to do, they let you autowin games but you don't FEEL like you're winning because you aren't doing anything or even noticing anything.

I'd venture that old Sona would still be super strong today.  This is a character who would be able to passively give Jhin unrestricted bonus AD and AP in lane.  A character that gives your team a locket aura and then can buy a second locket aura.  Those effects tend not to be appreciated, but are incredibly powerful in solo queue.

I do agree with you though that something felt a bit lost with the update.  She was this super spammy "push the buttons" character from very early on.  That was a lot of fun.  I think Rickless did a good job of getting that spammy feel back for the late game, but she still feels kinda at the whim of the people around her. My PERSONAL thoughts on Sona is that she could use a bit of personal agency (stuff that let's her react to bad things happening to her). That'd let Sona players feel more in control of their fates as the game goes on.

Any insight to his current power etc? I love that he's able to jungle and top and he's not pigeonholed bottom like a gem slave.

BTW, tell someone to make him some sort of Arclight or Project skin! Come on now, he's got this great new rig, use it!

I feel like you guys really nailed it with his Paladin Cecil Harvey style back story. Any insight to his current power etc? I love that he's able to jungle and top and he's not pigeonholed bottom like a gem slave.
> 

I personally LOVE Taric's new rework overall.  Think it does a good job of creating simple input paradigms that have the opportunity to create a lot of complex and exciting results.

My one gripe with it is that it might try to do to much at times (feels like all the spells hit all the things) and so individual actions (like his heal in lane) can come off feeling a little limp.

Also there's another side of me that really wishes we'd be more willing to keep the SUPER SIMPLE champions (like point and click stun old Taric) in the game as I feel League needs a couple really easy chars for players who want to focus on other aspects of the game (like learning how to lane or play around the map), as well as more targeted stuns in general to deal with all the crazy mobile characters. That's not a criticism of the new Taric however and more just a personal design yearning based off of how we tend to rework characters (point and click "easy" successes tend to be removed).

And yeah, his new theme is GODlike.

I am trying to get a response from someone in this Department that cares about Karma. You are at this point ignoring her. No one in your Department has given this champion the justice and work she deserves, especially after being the least worked on and lazy worked on champion. Legit . . . you guys completely BUTCHERED this champion with her relaunch. 90% of her problems can be fixed with a properly worked on visual update . . . which has YET to be worked on or completed.

I am asking that Riot seriously considers giving us her original visual update back . . . . and fix what little problems are wrong with that. The way the guy who worked on her handled Karma is insulting and very unprofessional. Yes the community whined. Her fans could have been put on a skin it made sense. Her dress could have been put on a skin. Yet you gave us a poorly worked on and oudated visual update. Again. Ignored.

https://i.ytimg.com/vi/zrHgmN6uoto/maxresdefault.jpg

She doesn't need a complete VGU. She needs minor work and her original PLANNED visual update applied. If you make the community wait the five to ten years you expect us to wait . . . . for you to do your 3 to 4 VGU a year . . . . League will be long gone. You don't care Riot games. Don't tell the community you care about a champion when  you have YET in the three years you butchered her . . . . you care.

It could be argued that the old Karma had some great stuff about her that didn't need to be changed.  It's possible we made some mistakes during her update. That was a very long time ago, however.  She's been new Karma for 3+ years and has aquired a new Karma fan base during that time that we will have to consider should we ever change her again. 

Personal opinion, is that at this point we should prolly focus on what is **currently** cool about her and make that as good as it can be (via balance or updates).  Dunno what we'll actually do with her though, as I'm not on the update team.

I just cannot comprehend how a comapny as big and successful as Riot Games cannot at least work on an already completed visual update and just work off of that. The masterminds behind her enitre identity destruction didn't listen to a single concern about any of her changes and gave us a half worked on visual update that cannot even have a proper running animation. 

I agree. You guys waited to long and now everyone is accustomed to a kit that really doesn't fit her theme and bottlenecks her mainly as a support. To be completely honest, you guys ptobaly did this on purpose just so you have another reason to not work on her. It's really telling us how much Riot Games cares about a champion they openly admit to botching, but have yet to do a single thing about her problems. Three years later and we have 7 Ryze reworks with a past visual update you used. It really makes you guys look very lazy and uncaring. I am not trying to attack you. It's just amazing how much you guys come off as not caring about Karma at all.

A numbers buff is just two clicks on a keyboard key with numbers on it. It's not work. It is a company trying to put a bandaid on a problem they haven't cared about for three years now.

Keep her current kit. What you really need to do is finish her visual update and maybe give her a new passive. None of this is too much to ask for. You haven't cared since then. At least do this.

I never said we botched her, I just said that old Karma may not have been as bad as we originally believed.  It's possible she didn't need that rework.  New Karma, in the grand scheme of things, is not an awful character though, and we need to care about her fan base.

You can believe what you like about things we do "on purpose" but at no point ever does anyone here say "let's just sit on it for 3 years and maybe the problem will go away."

The harsh reality of working at a game studio (even a big one like Riot is now) is that every single thing you do is taking resources away from something else.  Good particle artists that fit with your company culture are like magical unicorns in the games industry.  We can't just throw money at a problem until it's fixed.  We just straight up don't have the qualified manpower.  We have X employees to do Y work in Z amount of time.  Doing one thing means you don't do something else.

I'll give you a personal example.  I once found a bug on Vi that made her basic attacks sometimes lockup after using E.  Obviously it needed to be fix.  Simple right?  After looking into it I found out that wasn't the case.  It would take about 2 hours of design time for me to make it right.  I wanted to go fix the bug because I CARED about Vi players, but I was also working on Jinx at the time, and another champion that ended up getting canceled, and helping ideation team out with Braum (back when he was a spunky piltover girl called CeCe), and doing design one-on-ones with Meddler so I could grow and learn, and trying to go home and sleep before 1 am so I wouldn't get tired and sick.  It ended up taking me a month to get around to fixing that simple bug.

Look I understand that you're frustrated.  We took a character you loved and changed her and you see all these things that would make her so much better.  I feel you.  The problem is that a lot of things are not as easy as they seem.  I know you feel like we're villians here, but we're not trying to be.  No one at Riot is trying to be and if they are they should probably be fired.  We care about Karma, possibly not as much as you, but we care.  We just also care about Poppy, and Yorick, and Sion, and Ivern, and Tank Ekko's frustration problems, and the client update, and a seemingly endless list of things that makes any "easy" change a lot harder than it looks.

Sorry for jumping in. 
I have to start with a big **thank you**. Thank you for being honest, thank you for being kind, thank you for answering hard criticism with a detailed picture of the actual problem. Thank you for trying to enlighten us. Thank you for caring as much.

But let me return this kindness with a picture from our side:

* **It hurts** to read that you (Riot?) now seem to realize that Karma didn't need the rework as much as you thought she did. What the Karma community has/had been telling you for years.
* **It hurts** to read Meddler admitting that Karma has become bland because you didn't spend enough resources (thought, time) on her rework. 
* **It hurts** to see old Karma concepts (lvl6 abilities, shieldbomb) being salvaged and reused on new Champions, because it meant they were good concepts that didn't need to be removed, but also that they are unlikely to return to her, now that they are "taken".
* It hurts to read you saying, that the current Karma and her current fans need to be considered, when no one ever mentions that old Karma fans need to be considered. Or her valuable lost identity.

But I do agree. Those fans are a part of the Karma community now and time is precious. That is why I keep producing high quality rework suggestions, that try to be enjoyable for both sides. And try to save some time for you guys. Maybe you sometimes find the time to check out my latest two. They took me two months each to create:

* [A Detailed Post on Karma and her Twin Dragons](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/oxNbhh7j-a-detailed-post-on-karma-and-her-twin-dragons) (273 upvotes)
* [A Post about Duality, Overwatch and Karma](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/xh09E7aj-a-post-about-duality-overwatch-and-karma) (10 upvotes)

If you want to rework her theme, the first one is to be recommended. 
If you want to hammer down her current style, read the second one. 
Or maybe just keep them in mind if you ever want to check some opinions from the community. If you don't have the time personally, I do understand.

> Personal opinion, is that at this point we should prolly focus on what is currently cool about her and make that as good as it can be

No offense, but there isn't much. And the life update team managed to make her worse with every touchup since her rework (5.10 prominently). They don't know what's "cool" about her. Currently, Karma consists of boring overbuffed values and nothing unique. Fun things about her were her mantra mechanic, tether-touch mechanic and shieldbomb. Which was replaced with Heimer's ult, was removed and was removed. Her current version has too much of everything. She could have a niche as a battlemage/enchanter (not currently in the game). For that we would need to cut her CC, poke and burst and focus on her shield, speed, emergency heal and consistent damage. My reworks try to do this.

You don't have to answer, but I'd appreciate it if I could discern whether you read this or not. Either way, thank you again!

Thanks for the thought out response.  At this point I don't know that I have much more points to add to the Karma debate that I haven't already.  I'd like to respond to some of your ideas but I don't really want to put words into our live or rework team's mouths as to what we might (or might not) do to her in the future since they'd really just my personal opinion.

I will say that if this theme of duality you discuss is just cool in general (Ana is indeed a great  version of this in overwatch).  Think it's a bit harder to get right in League because of things like having heal power on a spell naturally needs it to take power hits in other areas (Ezreal W being the #1 example of where we had trouble with this stuff).  Nami certainly does this well with her W and R (Heal/hurt and haste/slow).  Interesting to think about other effect combos that would convert well to League...

What are your thoughts on Teemo purely from a gameplay perspective? He seems to have elements of assassin, marksman, and disruptor all mixed together in his kit. :P

P.S. When are you streaming again, I'm in the UK and I keep missing it. :(

He's amazing and I love him.  Teemo (like Singed and Blitz) is one of those weirdo champs in league that has a completely different game plan than any other character.  That's super valuable for our game as it introduces a lot of playing as and against variance that keeps league fresh.  

10/10 would buff (except the shroom AP ratio.  Screw those things dealing huge damage)
